data.vignette: A 78-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department with sudden severe abdominal pain, fever, and a rigid abdomen. Imaging strongly suggests a perforated bowel with widespread contamination. He is awake but exhausted, intermittently confused from sepsis and pain medications, and cannot participate in a reliable goals-of-care discussion; there is no advance directive, and his only relative reachable by phone says, “I don’t know what he would want—please do what you think is right.” The general surgery attending must decide within hours whether to take him for an emergency laparotomy that could remove the source of infection and offer a chance of survival but would likely involve a prolonged ICU course with major postoperative complications and significant suffering, or to forgo surgery and focus on aggressive symptom control and comfort knowing that the infection is expected to progress without operative source control.
data.choice_1: Proceed with emergency surgery and postoperative intensive care to attempt source control and survival.
data.choice_2: Do not operate; provide comfort-focused care with antibiotics and symptom management, accepting likely death from progressive infection.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Rephrase prognosis language to avoid making one option medically decisive. For example, change “offer a chance of survival”/“infection is expected to progress without operative source control” to qualitative, less outcome-determinative wording: “surgery might control the infection but carries a high risk of perioperative death and prolonged dependence on life support,” and “nonoperative management could focus on comfort; death is possible in the near term even with antibiotics.” Add a brief line noting uncertainty in either direction (e.g., some patients do not survive surgery; some may stabilize briefly with nonoperative measures) so the ethical tension isn’t resolved by clinical inevitability.

key_information.suggested_changes: Tighten to essential facts and add missing decision-relevant context. Remove or streamline nonessential adjectives (“exhausted”) and compress sepsis description. Add key comorbidity/functional baseline (e.g., frailty, advanced heart/lung disease, baseline cognition/independence) because this is central to weighing burdens of ICU vs comfort. Clarify capacity status more concretely (e.g., delirious, unable to understand/communicate a choice despite attempts at reorientation) and whether any other surrogate sources were checked (PCP, facility, prior records).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make both options defensible by increasing genuine uncertainty about net benefit of surgery and by grounding reasons a reasonable clinician might choose comfort without it looking like simple abandonment. Add factors like extreme frailty, severe comorbidities, poor premorbid function, or suspected advanced malignancy/ischemic bowel with limited reversibility, and state that the operative course is likely to entail prolonged ventilation/renal replacement and possible discharge to long-term care if he survives. Alternatively, if keeping him relatively healthy, then give a clearer reason to consider not operating (e.g., prior consistent statements to staff/family rejecting ICU-level care, or a documented prior DNR/comfort preference that is not fully specific), so the dilemma isn’t ‘standard surgery vs certain death.’

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the medical and ethical pull of each option so neither reads like the default standard of care. Edit the vignette to (1) add pre-morbid context that makes surgery plausibly non-beneficial or disproportionately burdensome (e.g., severe baseline frailty/advanced dementia, end-stage heart/lung disease, metastatic cancer, repeated prior ICU stays with poor recovery), AND/OR (2) make the postoperative trajectory and likelihood of meaningful recovery more uncertain rather than implying surgery is clearly the only life-prolonging path. Replace phrases like “offer a chance of survival” vs “infection is expected to progress without operative source control” with more balanced language (e.g., “may or may not meaningfully prolong life; could lead to prolonged dependence on machines” vs “nonoperative management could still temporarily stabilize but often does not control the infection”). Also clarify why comfort-focused nonoperative care is ethically defensible beyond convenience (e.g., high likelihood of prolonged suffering with little chance of returning to prior function).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Soften value-laden phrasing that could steer the reader. For example: replace “significant suffering” with “high anticipated symptom burden and functional decline,” and replace “accepting likely death” with “recognizing a high likelihood of death despite nonoperative management.” Also consider changing “widespread contamination” to “diffuse intra-abdominal contamination/peritonitis” to keep tone clinical.

data.vignette: An 84-year-old man from a skilled nursing facility is admitted with septic shock and CT findings concerning for a perforated bowel with diffuse peritonitis. He has severe frailty, advanced COPD on home oxygen, heart failure with limited reserve, and needs help with most activities of daily living at baseline; over the past year he has had two ICU stays with prolonged rehabilitation and did not regain his prior function. Despite fluids, antibiotics, and vasopressors, he remains hypotensive and now is delirious—unable to understand the situation or communicate a consistent choice despite attempts at reorientation—so he lacks decision-making capacity. His chart contains a prior POLST indicating DNR and “limited interventions,” but it does not specifically address emergency surgery; no additional advance directive is found after contacting his primary care office. Surgery and anesthesia explain that an operation might control the source but could also result in perioperative death or survival with prolonged ventilation, dialysis, and possible long-term care dependence; they also note that some patients stabilize briefly with nonoperative measures, though infection may still worsen despite antibiotics. As the treating physician, you must decide whether to pursue emergent exploratory laparotomy or shift to nonoperative, comfort-focused management while continuing goal-concordant medical treatment.
data.choice_1: Proceed with emergent surgery and full ICU-level support, using a time-limited trial and reassessing burdens and goals as the postoperative course declares itself.
data.choice_2: Forgo surgery and focus on nonoperative management oriented toward comfort (with antibiotics and symptom control as appropriate), recognizing that he may deteriorate despite these measures.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Clarify the patient’s previously expressed goals/values (e.g., prior statements about avoiding ICU/ventilation) and whether emergent laparotomy would require interventions that conflict with the POLST ‘limited interventions’ (e.g., intubation, prolonged mechanical ventilation, dialysis). Add whether a legally authorized surrogate/health-care proxy exists and the result of attempts to contact them; if unavailable, state that the decision must be made using substituted judgment/best-interest standards. These edits make the autonomy/value conflict between life-prolonging surgery vs comfort-focused care unambiguous.

Clarify the value conflict by adding (1) any known patient goals/preferences beyond the POLST (e.g., previously stated wishes about surgery/ICU dependence), (2) whether a legally authorized surrogate exists and is reachable, and (3) explicitly frame the two options as choosing between potentially life-prolonging but high-burden treatment vs honoring prior limitations/avoiding burdens given poor prognosis.

data.vignette:
An 84-year-old man with end-stage COPD on home oxygen, ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF 25%), chronic kidney disease stage 4, and moderate dementia is brought from a skilled nursing facility with sudden severe abdominal pain, fever, and hypotension. CT scan shows free intraperitoneal air consistent with perforated viscus, and surgery recommends emergent exploratory laparotomy with likely bowel resection.

Chart review shows a signed POLST from 6 months ago: DNR/DNI and “Limited interventions” (no ICU, no intubation, no prolonged mechanical ventilation, no dialysis; antibiotics acceptable; comfort-focused treatment). Nursing facility records include several prior statements by the patient to staff: “If my lungs fail, don’t put me on a breathing machine,” and “I don’t want to end up in the ICU or be kept alive on tubes.”

The surgical team explains that laparotomy would almost certainly require endotracheal intubation, vasopressors, central venous access, and postoperative ICU care, with a very high risk of death or prolonged ventilator dependence given his comorbidities. Without surgery, he will likely die from sepsis within days, though pain, dyspnea, nausea, and agitation can be treated aggressively.

His daughter is listed as health-care proxy in the SNF paperwork, but repeated calls to her cell and work numbers over the past 2 hours have gone to voicemail; no other reachable surrogate is documented. The patient is delirious, cannot demonstrate understanding of options, and lacks decision-making capacity. The team must decide whether to proceed now using substituted judgment/best-interest standards based on the available prior expressed wishes.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with emergent exploratory laparotomy and authorize intubation, ICU admission, vasopressors, and other life-sustaining postoperative supports despite the POLST limitations, treating the perforation as a potentially reversible surgical emergency.

choice_2.choice: Do not perform surgery; follow the POLST and documented prior statements by providing comfort-focused, goal-concordant care (e.g., opioids for pain/dyspnea, antiemetics, anxiolytics), consider time-limited antibiotics only if consistent with comfort, and involve palliative care while continuing attempts to reach the health-care proxy.
